text: - Hello and welcome to Community Chats.
I'm your host Aley Hammer

and today we're joined with
John Boesen, the CTO at Symbio.
John, welcome to the show.
Can you start by telling our audience
a little bit about Symbio and your role?

- Yeah, thanks, Aley,
it's great to be here.

Look, Symbio is a great
Australian success story
which a lot of people don't know about.
So we were founded in 2002
under a business called MyNetFone

and we had a simple mission
to transform the way

voice communications would
be delivered to households,

small/medium business
enterprise, government,

and it was all underpinned
by a new technology

called Voice over IP, which
now is sort of everywhere
and everyone's heard about that,
but what we were really founded to do

was bridge this Voice over IP
world with this Telco world

because the two worlds
were very, very different.

Now, the interesting thing
was, is a couple of years

after we founded, Skype surfaced
and hopefully many of you
have probably used Skype in your time,

but Skype was a classic
software-based as a service company
providing Voice over IP connectivity

between computer and computer,
but when it first launched,
you couldn't make a phone call from Skype
to a telephone number and that's where we

came in to the fold and
we were actually Skype's

seventh customer globally,
partner globally,

and what we did is we provided
this software approach

to Telco so we sort of
look like two companies.
So to a Telco, we look like a Telco.
We build infrastructure
and we build networks and we interconnect

to telecommunication
incumbents in countries,
but we also, the other half,
we look like a purebred software company.
So to Skype, that's what we looked like.
We look like a software company

and they were able to use
our software APIs that we

had created to hide all the
complexity of being a Telco

and that is how they
were able to integrate

local number calling
capability into their products.
And now, you know, 20 years on,

that's pretty much what
Symbio lives and breathes now
is we're powering a lot of technology,
a lot of big players that you would use
in your everyday life.

Actually, even the Zoom
call that we're using today,

the phone numbers that are
presented in the Zoom calls
are actually on our network.
So we've basically created this bridge

between the software
world and the Telco world.

In terms of I guess my
role in the organization,
ultimately I'm responsible for driving

our technology strategy
that's gonna execute

our company strategy which is
now to deploy our technology

across Southeast Asia,
but specifically my role
is to make sure our tech stack can scale.

It has the aspirations
of having 100% uptime.

You know, there's no point
talking about Five 9s anymore.

That's sort of like, okay,
well that's standard.
So we aspire to have 100% uptime.

In everything we do, we
try and achieve that.
It's very difficult to achieve,
but that's what we try and do.
We try and do it in a frictionless way,
so we really wanna make sure

that where it's transparent
as possible to our customers

and the rest of the business,
but a big part of my role

is also about building
the engineering culture

within the company and really
challenging them to grow
and to learn from success and failure,

but ultimately the best part,
I guess in my role is just,

you know, working with a
lot of talented individuals

that are at different parts
of their career development

and just helping guide them
and pushing them to do things

that they thought they couldn't
do and with an ultimate view
to do things better than yesterday.

So, yeah, that's the sort of
overview of Symbio and my role.
- Thank you so much, John.
I mean, your team is so lucky to have you.
Just in the the description there,
it sounds like you love the company.
What you're doing is so incredible.

So I wanted to ask you,
John, because Symbio
recently had a major restructure,

so can you walk us through a
little bit about what's changed

and what does this actually
mean for Symbio's customers?

- Yeah, look, we previously
operated as a monolith

so we were effectively
a shared services group,
so technology within Symbio
was effectively a shared services group

and with that came a lot of
prioritization conversations.
Because we were a shared resource pool,

we had to make sure that
everyone got fed, if you like,

that we could deliver what
their customers were wanting,
but it did create a lot of friction

and a lot of inefficiency
and part of our culture,
which is a learning-based culture,
we wanted to challenge ourselves,
say is there a better way to do this.

So we did some experiments,
we tried a few things,

some failed, but a couple
of our experiments worked

and what that led us to was
to break into three lines
of business that were targeted

to the three customer
personas that we saw.
So we saw our different customers

that we were servicing
were very different.
Everyone had different requirements
and were coming from different angles,
they had different problems to solve,

so we effectively realigned
into what we call UCaaS,

Unified Communications
as a Service division,

CPaaS, Communication
Platform as a Service,

and one we call TaaS, which
is Telco as a Service,

and they sort of map to,
the Telco as a Service

maps to small/medium business,
and the UCaaS and CPaaS one

sort of map to enterprise and
government with a few twists.
So we effectively broke the monolith
into three sort of macro services
or micro services or agile startups
is the best way I like to think about it,

but they operate under the
banner of a global group,
cbo.global, and that sort of gives with it
the stability of an established business

and it gives us the flexibility
and agility of a startup

so that's translated
then into our customers

getting what they need
quicker because these lines
of businesses that we created,

we also made sure that
they were full stack,
so full stack beyond technology,

so not only in tech circles,
you talk about full stack,

you talk about frontend,
backend, so on and so forth.
We really full stack these organizations
so that we have sales, operations,
everything that you need to run a business

and that was pretty
much the heart and soul,

the transformation we went
through about 12 months ago.

- Well, it definitely
sounds like you've learned
a lot along the way and, John,
Symbio launched a full suite of services

in Singapore recently and it's
expanding all across Asia,
so how has your team been able to launch

a full suite of services in
just a couple of weeks actually
when it often takes others several months

or even, quite frankly, several
years, how did you do this?

- Yeah, well look, it
certainly started from us

being in that situation where
it did take us many years
to deploy our technology.

In fact, Australia was our
first market that we built

and that literally took
five to seven years
to build that network.
We then went into New Zealand
and that took about five years.

And then we went, well,
look for us to scale,

we can't keep doing what we're
doing, so Singapore for us,

even though it took us three
years to get into Singapore,

behind the scenes, we were
investing heavily in our people
to upskill them into all things AWS,

which is what we did initially
and we started to modernize
all of our processes, build pipelines.
We were adopting CI/CD principles.

We were using Terraform
and taking infrastructure
as code methodologies to everything we do.
In actual fact, all our tech stack now

is infrastructure as code so
there was a lot of learning

and growth and upskilling
that we invested in

and we made a lot of
mistakes too along that way,

but that led us to a place
where we could now deploy

our ecosystem behind closed
doors literally within days

where as previously we
would've had to build
all this infrastructure
with this infrastructure-fixed mindset.

So in the three program
of work for Singapore,

even though externally it looks
like it took us three years
to deploy Singapore, behind the scenes

we had done all this
upskilling, all this uplifting

and some other major
architectural changes as well
to move away from a monolithic approach,

to move to real time
streaming event model,
to abstract all our interfaces

so teams could deploy
frequently and often.
So there was a lot of things that we did,

but yeah it was a mix
of all those approaches
that has now led us to a great position
for us to now tackle our next market

in a third of the time
it took for Singapore.
- John, to round up this interview,
how has your leadership style evolved
since the pandemic began?
Have you learned anything new

that could be of value
to other aspiring CTOs
who may be watching this video?
- Well, yeah, look, well, first of all,

I feel as though I'm
always learning, right?

I'm always evolving, I guess,
as a person, as a leader

and I expect that of all
my team and staff as well,

but look, lockdown really
forced a different approach.
People used to drop into the office.
That no longer happened.

I could have physical
events where I could talk
to the masses and communicate
some pretty important messaging
so I had to switch to Colab platforms

and teams played a fairly
important role for us.

I sort of had to brush up
on my presentation skills

through a screen, though
not always successfully,

to try and connect to
people and show emotion
and expression and even in this interview
I'm sort of using my hands here
which I never used to do that much of,

but you try to add these
other levels of connectivity
to how you're communicating with people.

We introduced things
like real time polling

so we could have that
interaction from the audience.
We moved to a large teams' meeting
where everyone would join.
Their mics were all on.

Everyone had to respect each
other and turn the mics off

'cause we wanted high
degrees of collaboration.

But I think during that whole
process for me, you know,

never lose sight of your
people and their growth.

That's really important
because a lot of what we do

as technologists is here
to stay for many years
and a lot of the projects we work on

are multi-year projects so
you've gotta grow your people

on that journey so you've
really gotta think about that.
Don't be afraid to make big bets,
even though you probably know your team
can't deliver it in the here and now,

you definitely always
wanna be real, right,
because you're gonna be held accountable

by your managers or your
exec team or your board

so you don't wanna walk
the team off a cliff,

but you definitely want to
set some aspirational goals
that maybe even challenge you.
But what I can guarantee you is
that those little steps that you take
towards that goal will get you there

and then when you get there,
you'll look back and go,
"Oh my God, we've actually done it."

I think it's really important
to celebrate those successes
as well when you achieve them.

But I think most important
for young leaders
or aspiring CTOs is just remember

you're are always one
cog of a bigger wheel.
You're not at the top of the wheel.
You're not the engine by any means.
You're just another cog in that wheel
and it's important for you to understand
the purpose of your cog in the bigger team

and to make sure that it's
adding value to the team

and the only way you can
achieve that is by asking
lots of questions and saying,
"Hey, am I giving you what you need?
Am I helping you out here?
Is there anything that you need?
Is there something I'm not doing?"
But once you've got that clarity,
it's in a collective, right?
It's then working together as a team.
I have my role to do.

I've got the luxury of having
this chat today with you guys
while many of my team are working hard
at doing what they've gotta do.
It's a collaborative team effort,
but that's probably the big takeaway.

Just remember that you are
just a cog in the wheel.

- Absolutely, I mean, I
think even if you're the CEO,

the MD, it doesn't matter,
that that stands true.

So thank you so much, John,
for coming in the show today.

The partnership between
Symbio and Amazon is amazing.

I cannot wait to continue to
watch the journey between us
and if anyone has any questions,

please pop them in the
comment section below
and we'll get back to you.
Thanks so much, John.
- Thanks, Aley, thanks very much.
